>>56776857
A document describing the upcoming NGSW rounds make note of a "General Purpose" and "Special Purpose" round both boasting 'enhanced penetrative capabilities' or whatever the hell, & making use of elements related to the design of the XM1158 ADVAP round (tungsten cored M80A1, essentially). Tungsten is highly unlikely to be viable as a general issue bullet material for reasons of cost and supply as described, plus the special round obviously must do something better than the general purpose round.

For training, there's no particular reason to exclusively use the EPR design if you're not going to actually use that bullet in any other role, as it confers no major benefits for practice alone. You could just use a conventional FMJ with a similar ballistic trajectory without having to go through the trouble of increased expense and design complexity. The only real reason to use an EPR-style round for training is if you were using the same bullet in combat and just wanted to simplify logistics, bullet behavior, etc.

There are also pictures of a conceptual 6.8x51 military round which was an EPR design, and then a photo recently released of the current ammo showed pretty much exactly the same thing.

So everything so far would suggest the standard issue combat round is a steel core EPR design.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56774697
>even the civilian version can fully compromise the plate in a single shot.
Which civilian version are you speaking of? The all-brass case FMJ? That loading runs weaker than NIJ spec M80 and almost all Level 4 plates can stop multiple rounds of M80, in fact that is an explicit requirement for NIJ Level 3 classification (which level 4 plates are not technically required to meet, but almost always exceed in practice). Most Level 4 plates in fact will prevent penetration from multiple M2 AP rounds as well unless you stack them on top of each other.

>Based on the demonstration of the civilian elite ball FMJ that i've seen, a faster version carrying even a steel penetrator would punch through it.
No, it almost certainly wouldn't. That's a 135 gr bullet traveling at about 2600 FPS out of a 13" barrel. The NIJ Spec M2 AP round is a steel core bullet weighing 163 gr traveling at 2880 FPS.

We have seen some level 4 plates stop 130 gr M80A1 at ~3500 FPS, and M2 AP at over 3300 FPS, so safe to say that several armors offer protection far in excess of what all-brass 6.8x51 would be capable of.

>Going up from there, we are looking at the very much theoretical type V infantry mobile armor of which all current versions are considered far to heavy to be practical
They aren't. There are already several plates that are explicitly rated for protection beyond NIJ Spec M2 AP. The XSAPI, Adept Armor Colossus, Stealth Armor Systems Hexar, LTC 28601 and Tencate CX-950 IC are all examples of this.

The lightest of those is only 6.5 lb (or maybe even a little lighter, if you include the VTP XSAPI). The most durable one that we have seen so far (which is also, coincidentally, the lightest - again, not including the VTP XSAPI) can stop M993 rounds traveling at over 3400 FPS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56776232
I wore corcoran black jump boots all through college in the 80's, but afaik they haven't changed much since then. They fit true to size, I measure 9 1/2E on a brannock and that's the size I wear in jump boots. They are reasonably well built, the leather is a bit thin but they have reinforcement at wear points so they will last for years. They have great ankle support (which is why I wore them, I sprained my ankle twice in a few weeks my freshman year and my rotc friend recommended them). The soles do not have particularly good traction (you will slip on wet grass) but they last a good while and your local cobbler can resole them with a grippy modern vibram sole when the time comes.

The only other negative is they don't have speed hooks and their lace holes are close together so getting in them can take awhile. I'm actually pondering getting a pair of browns myself and cutting them down to about 7" which should make it considerably faster to get in and out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56775328
Glock has a different locking geometry, different extractor, different takedown and the whole trigger/striker mechanism is something else entirely.

Beretta has the same locking mechanism, the trigger mechanism is essentially the same (minor rearrangement), different recoil spring placement, same takedown, same extractor, same safety, wider magazine.

if you take a P38, lengthen the slide, widen the magazine well and put the recoil spring underneath the barrel, you essentially have a Beretta 92. you can't make a Glock out of a Hi Power with so few changes.

Not watching the lowbrow clip.
Here my expert and autistic elevator pitch assessment.
Troop evaluation:
Mediocre to decent in comparison to Norwegian, Swedish, German, Danish, Dutch, Austrian and British troops. The population isn’t the most innovative, but stubborn rather organized and patriotic. Historically speaking they excelled under German command. Most of the relevant - male - population is trained and studies suggest more ready to defend their country in comparison to other WEIRD countries.
Equipment structure evaluation:
Weak Air Force and rather weak air defense (not too bad population wise), weak fleet, a lot of artillery (most of it isn’t really great), decent tanks, a lot of cheap mines, infantry weapons especially sniper rifles, assault rifles and mortars (a lot of it is a good idea give modern warfare).
Lack of modern battlefield awareness. Which limits offensive operations.
Geography:
Mostly protected by sea, lakes, hills and and forest. Coastline mostly averse to large landing operations.
Terrain favorable for defense.
Climate type subarctic; which means rather harsh winters and swampy surface in the summer.
Climate favorable for defense.
Strategy assessment:
Very low offensive potential. Today that’s drones, cruise and ballistic missiles and the platforms to lunch them from sea, land and air.
Moderat to high defensive potential given terrain, climate and mobilization potential, large equipment storage.
Conclusion:
Mix of western and eastern strategy. With mass mobilization and huge storage of old weapons. Focused on defensive operations and terrain optimized operations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56778760
.45acp 230gr is indeed naturally subsonic, same as 147gr 9mm and both are relatively quiet out of a 16" barrel.
Statistically, there is no difference in outcome between use of 9mm and .45acp. There is no functional difference. I would go the 9mm instead or 10mm because I love 10mm and the extra penetration abilities are useful in some situations.
However, my argument is the same. I have a trained a lot for a long time with pistols. I can hit what I'm aiming at real good with a handgun. So to me a handgun is just better for moving around corners and being able to use 1 handed.
Let's say hypothetically you hear a bump in the night. What do you do? You aren't going to call the cops if you don't know what it is. You're going to go find it. You're going to take your HD weapon of choice. Now picture yourself exiting your bedroom. You're in a narrow hallway. Now you have to turn a sharp corner. At any moment an intruder could lunge at you with zero a zero distance gap. If you chose a longer gun, they may have grabbed the barrel first as you rounded that corner with it. You have to take your support hand off to manipulate door handles and light switches. My belief is that a handgun is something I can keep closer to my body, manage tight corners better with and still retain 90% use while my support hand is occupied elsewise.
Then if I actually do have to shoot it, I keep a short suppressor on it which is still loud enough to scare someone but is light enough the gun cycles confidently. It will also not cause permanent hearing damage. The trade off is that the handgun lacks stopping power. So, training is even more important.

Just out of curiousity, how many times have you practiced clearing your house with your gun? I'd recommend it.

I don't know what source you read but there's no regulation against pointy tips, the recap is
>blade must not be longer than 12cm
>double edge blades are forbidden
>folding knives with auto deployment are forbidden

That's pretty easy to understand, now the tricky part is that it's up to the police to decide if you have a valid reason to carry a knife, and if they decide you don't, they can't take it away from you and you can even get a fine.
Common example, you are out fishing at the beach, it's OK for you to carry a knife. You are at the pub on a Saturday night, it is not OK for you to carry a knife.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56751525
I can only speak for Germany and its surrounds, but there's plenty of shops to be getting interesting stuff from here. mostly well known, though. I'm just gonna name what comes to mind in no particular order.
Brandners homestyle for french, italian and spanish traditionals
Tools For Gents and Selected Knives for expensive fancy stuff and exclusives (not just knives). TfG had a 30% on everything sale over black friday, that was pretty good.
There's austrian shop knifeshop.com especially good for modern, classic and even used vintage Italian autos (AKC Beltrame, AGA Campolin, the latter company runs the shop) which sometimes have quick sales on with 30-40% discount.
knyfe.de seems pretty unknown too, not that interesting but sometimes quick sales, like recently they had a pair of coldsteel swords for 40% discount.
wolfster.de had some interesting stuff sometimes (I kinda regret that I didn't buy some anso designed titanium+cruwear Böker back in 2019 when they sold it for just 80 bucks), but that company is gone.
bq-warehouse mostly has an identical repertoire to boker.de, but sometimes cheaper. their prices are weirdly crooked (they'll sell something for 72,64€ if they want, not on the full euro) but the company is trustworthy.
knifestock.de is a slovakian company, they've got a lot of czech Mikov stuff, even more specialty like the (illegal in Germany due to blade length) Predator automatic in damascus steel.
outnorth is a Swedish outdoor shop, over black Friday they had Moras at great prices. got myself a Kansbol for 27€.
Jusaya and messerundco have chinese imports from sanrenmu and the like, that often can't be gotten anywhere else. the latter also has new old stock knives from Solingen from the 70s and 80s.
and there's Messerdepot and com2youbiwak and Söldner-Messer and probably several more

>>56755882
The Lucha is considered by many to be the absolute best for it's price range, but that price range is around $120 or so and will probably be in a different class from $600 knives.
I find it to be a very sturdy, well-tuned, smooth-flipping knife with no play. It's quite heavy for a bali though, and a lot of people describe it being like a brick. I think it's nice and performs very well though, but I imagine if you want to do super advanced tricks you might prefer something lighter, but it's still doable.

I'm super curious if anyone knows if store-knives.com is reputable, because they appear to have some crazy deals on Maxace balis, some of which are in the $500-range that seem to be on sale for around $90-$100. One of those is the Apostle, which I've been wanting for a while.

Maxace is known for having top-notch support and the knives you buy from them apparently come with a free extra set of screws, bushings, and even a trainer blade you can switch out.

>>56775588
ehhh try a winter coat with a sweatshirt under it and then some meat under there. and keep in mind that IRL all that stuff isn't going to be sandwiched together tightly, and it will be moving and reacting. with a Matriarch slash you will do better than any regular edge 3.5" knife but you will still barely scratch the flesh or do nothing in many circumstances.

on the other hand a coat will do almost nothing to stop a drop point knife's stab, even if they aren't optimally shaped for stabbing. the only thing that will put up resistance is stuff in the pockets like you mentioned, or zippers, buttons, etc. i would be far more concerned about any dude icepick gripping a random 3.5" drop point rather than someone wielding a Civilian or Matriarch. those knives are sold on this weird premise that you can just wave them around and you'll slice and dice someone up, but that just isn't how it works lol. good luck dealing meaningful damage to the arms of picrel. hammer gripping a knife and then stabbing the shit out of them is not at all more complicated, it defeats more "armor", and on average it deals more lethal or debilitating damage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56769274
Depends what kind of threats it has to fight against.
If it's only fighting long range bombers and cruise missiles it doesn't have to be stealthy.
It also depends on the territory it has to cover and the budget.
If you have not too much territory to cover and can afford enough Interceptors, then you can make a high supersonic, high performance focused design, probably a trapezoid/delta (IE mirage etc)
If you have to cover more area with less jets you might make something with a bit more range and better subsonic performance.
Of course in the modern day you can build jets with super-cruise capability so that might be desirable for a long range interceptor.

I think for this role UAVs might do really well, the task is fairly simple and because you are operating over friendly territory, jamming and maintaining communication is not such an issue.

>I have a question. You described unusually advanced weapons for a medieval period.
Not really. Medieval times started with firearms and ended with firearms. Grenades were already a thing in the VIIth century. Multiple rocket launchers appeared during the Xth century in China.
Yes for Europe some of these weapons may be two or three centuries early. But the knowledge was already there somewhere else in the world anyway.
>Why do expect the average local bodger and blacksmith to be able to cobble that shit together?
They weren't as good as the best roman and greek late antiquity inventors and scientists, but still very good. They also had excellent ability to absorb new knowledge and reproduce it thanks to the guild system, which is particularly visible in architecture.
>Something like a multi-barreled breech loading rifle would have been a masterwork taking years upon years with the finest craftsmen of the age.
Correct. But I only need them to make small easy parts. They had all the tooling needed to do that especially if I provide go/no-go gauges or related tooling.
>far too complicated to be duplicated at all let alone mass-produced.
The battle of Castillon which ended the 100 years saw the use of 300 guns, sure it was late medieval times, but this proves you could get big numbers.
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Castillon
>The French army was commanded by committee; Charles VII's ordnance officer Jean Bureau laid out the camp to maximize French artillery strength. In a defensive setup, Bureau's forces built an artillery park out of range from Castillon's guns. According to Desmond Seward, the park "consisted of a deep trench with a wall of earth behind it which was strengthened by tree-trunks; its most remarkable feature was the irregular, wavy line of the ditch and earthwork, which enabled the guns to enfilade any attackers". The park included up to 300 guns of various sizes

>>56775731
>Not really. Medieval times started with firearms and ended with firearms
"firearms" sure. But not the level of sophistication you described. You're doing the equivalent of asking Henry Ford to build the Bugatti Veyron because he built the model T.

>They had all the tooling needed to do that
Anon, the concept of using "tooling" to produce firearms with interchangeable parts didn't exist until the 19th century. Before then everything was done by hand. Go read The Gun and Its Development by Greener if you haven't already.

>They weren't as good as the best roman and greek late antiquity inventors and scientists, but still very good
The average one could barely make a farm tool. There absolutely were craftsmen who could make things like you described but there were very very few people with that level of skill alive.

> but this proves you could get big numbers.
Big numbers of very simple matchlocks does not translate to big numbers of gatling guns or a multi-barreled breech loading rifle. We can't make very many multi-barreled guns if we don't have very many barrels in the first place.

I think a deathclaws main advantage as a bioengeneered living weapon is that they are agressive , tough and fast enough to reach you and rip your powerarmored arm off before you can put enough holes in them with a standard issue weapon (556 service rifle, 5mm assault carbine , 10 and 9mm pistols, 12 gauge buckshot, 308 boltaction, or a 40mm gl frag) to put them down immediately. A 50 cal, 5mm minigun , rocketlauncher, laser gatling, should put one down fast.

The fact that they will likely die from collapsed lungs/bleeding a fiew minutes later because your mangaled corpse shot it 7 times with your service rifle is irrelevant to your dead ass.

They might have some strategically engenneered defenses like:
> a extremely thickened sternum for heart protection,
>enamel layer on top of a bone layer of the cranium and ribcage
>semirigid periosteum to reduce mobility loss from bonebreaks,

>isolated left and right lung to function for longer/ possibly survive despite a sucking chestwound,

>thickened elongated skulls with a lot of sinuses to absorb some pistol fire and possibly deflect/ stop some rifle calibers (not all of them)

>Tougher , thicker skin to stop frag grenades and mines from disabling your geneticaly moded weapon.

>Denser muscles to prevent smgs from reaching internal organs as easily and provide instadeath power output

They are also stealthy and perceptive so you likely wont see them coming an a military deployment untill it is too late

ok here's what you need to do

Set strength, endurance, intelligence, agility, and luck to 7. Allocate the remaining points how you see fit (I recommend putting them into agility, strength, and luck).

Hat - 1st recon beret
Armor - courier duster
Other hat to go with first hat - the stupid 3 ring thing from old world blues
Perks - finesse, grunt, cowboy, intense training (to put points into the main stats)

You'll also need the modpack "Viva New Vegas", as well as the individual mods "Classic Fallout Weapons Remastered" and "Weapons of the New Millennia and Friends", and optionally you'll want "TF2 critical hit sounds" and "Faster Semi-Auto Fire Rate".


Pretty much any weapon should be viable now so long as you can fire it fast enough, though I prefer Joshua Graham's gun, I killed every last NCR trooper and legionnaire on the dam with it last night. That was fun.

>>56774666
But Germans have nothing to do with it, it's a convention for investors to take Germany as an example of really low risk investment, we could use Norway instead of Germany to compare spread too. Spread is only about the entity of the risk you take in investing on a certain country's title: Germany have really low risks regarding investments and really low interest rates AKA if you invest your money in Germany's bunds you won't turn 100k in 110k, in 10 years, at best you are preventing your money to lose value due to inflation. If instead you invest in a risky country like Italy's BTP you will get higher interests rates (no one would make a risky investment without the prospect of getting a higher revenue from it) and you could easily turn 100k in 110k or more in 10 years.
Spread its a measure that markets and investors use to understand how risky an investment is and, generally speaking, if you are risking more you could gain more money from it. It's the same principle or sport's bets but instead of "which team is stronger" you base it on "which country is more stable"

>>56773997
If this is serious thread and not another gopnik desperation slide thread, economic warfare in the cold state is called mercantilism and means a government supporting and using private industry directly to exert foreign influence. East India Company and Royal African Company would be notable examples.
At its lowest ebb, mercantilism is a way for one country to maintain an edge over a rival, like China pegging it's currency under the dollar, but it can go up to outright stripping of resources and territory economically and politically - think United Fruit or rubber plantations in Liberia in the 1900s.
Mercantilism crosses over into a hot war when one country makes an outright denial of trade on another- a blockade of any kind, for example, is considered an act of war.
None of the shit you posted about counts as such, however so go hit up Brittanica online and read up on mercantilism before replying, fuckface

Think: inside the same room, or across the table in a bar/restaurant. At that range you are almost quaranteed to get a hit in vital organs so any "stopping power" doesn't really matter.

My dad has a walther PP (the slightly longer one) and yeah, I'd recon it would get the job done. You have to be careful though, since it is prone for slide bite. The slide is awfully low and close to your hand.

So any small .380 pocket pistol should get the job done, as long as it's reliable. I have heard good things about Glock 42, although it is a bit bigger than Rulger LCP or Kahr. Been hearing rumours that those two are not as great as they seem on the paper, but I have no personal experience.

But Walther PP/PPK I would trust.

posts.com:
Hello /k/ommandos, i/diy/ot visitor here. I don't know jack shit about bowyery but I've always wanted to make a semi-automatic crossbow so figured why not just try it out. I have plans for further improvements - extended magazine, greater draw force, improve compactness, eventually even using spring-fed interchangeable magazines rather than gravity. Here's a video of test firing today:
https://www.youtube.com/shorts/0Ghmfe2TyEA
But right now it seems the biggest limiting factor for performance is the bolts and could use some recommendations in this regard (note how much they veer in flight - probably doesn't help that I carved tapers in with a knife because belt sanding was too slow). Bolts currently must fit within the profile of a 3/8" diameter - no fletching. Doing some research it seems that the Chinese didn't using fletching for their Chu Ko Nu bolts and it was just a spray and pray weapon.
They about 8 inches in length. For proof of concept I just sanded a point on one side and a taper on the other. I plan to make some steel cones on the lathe (with a protrusion to mate with a hole on the shaft), heat treat them, then probably just glue them into the hole in the shaft..
Would cutting either spiral or straight fluting on the shaft improve accuracy? Should I change the length to diameter ratio? Would be hard pressed to make bolts larger but could do some redesign to shrink length or diameter. Or any other tips.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56778484
Joerg Sprave explored the repeating crossbow concept and took it very far. He insists that a long under-lever design lets you get much more power, and he's got a few designs for magazines and small scale bolts that will feed in them. I suggest you look up his projects on youtube, he does all sorts of wacky shit but search "Crossbow" or "repeating" or something.

But I'm starting to think I'll go ahead and make this into a bipod firing bow, then make a smaller hip-firing bow once I get everything else figured out.

>>56721620
That's probably prop department shit but a pistol or scout scope could probably work. Just don't shoot too fast. It'd probably wander a little when heating up though but there's only one way to tell; find a spare "suppressor" and get a gunsmith to attach a rail to that shit. Or draw a centerline and drill and tap it yourself. Use a picatinny rail section that is made for round top guns that has screw holes pre-drilled. If it's the wrong radius on the bottom, simply tape a section of fine (400+ grit) sandpaper to your "suppressor" and run the rail along it until it's conformed to the shape well enough. Could always shove some JB Weld under it too if it doesn't seem to keep zero. Oh yeah and remember to make sure it's clocked correctly on the gun BEFORE you drill and tap it for a rail (eg. put it on the gun and mark the very top somehow). Could go the crush washer route as well if its clocking ever gets screwed up. A "suppressor" with wrench flats could help you get it clocked the same every time and snug enough that it won't unscrew itself.

Disclaimer: I'm not a gunsmith, nor have I ever tried that, but it works in my head. Use some shitty cheap Barska scope if you want to try this since who knows what it'll do to the scope. Just replace those garbage Barska rings first.

>>56768611
>It's a full auto gun by design. All it does is shoot 9mm
So are a ton of other guns on the market. The TP9 is the lightest and most compact 9mm PDW on the market outside of braced pistols or pistol chassis while also having less recoil than braced pistols or pistol chassis. No other gun on the market does what it does. Is that extremely niche? Yes. Where the TP9 shines is that it’s tiny and weighs less than five pounds empty with a micro red dot, a light, the vertical grip, and the stock. Nothing else on the market can do the specific thing that it does as well as it does.

Even with all my praise though I don’t want one, I don’t need a gun to do the specific things that it excels at. Maybe if it was like half the cost but it’s not worth it to me. They’re fun to shoot though and fun to goof around with but let’s be real who really needs the lightest most compact 9mm PDW on the market unless they just specifically want a TP9 because they think it’s cool (perfectly valid reason and they’re cool af)?

posts.sub: Are 16" actually the best all around?
posts.com:
Despite the fact that 16" is the shortest legal length without going through the ATF, are they unironically the best length? They are short enough to be light and handy but are long enough to retain accuracy and velocity.

I dont see much point in having a 5.56 gun shorter than 14.5" or longer than 18"

After 18" the velocity gains are not worth adding any more length, and shorter than 14.5" is reducing velocity too much for a round that is highly velocity dependent.

Am I right or am I just a cuck coping with the fact that I cant own a gun shorter than 16"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56780217
No it's a good length. 95% of the velocity of a 20 inch barrel, but 80% as long.

I would argue that 14.5 has 92% of the velocity and loses another 1.5 inches, but 1.5 inches is really not worth the $200 tax stamp. Anything shorter really starts to lose velocity fast, and Mk18s are going out of style rapidly as operators realized that 10.5 inch barrels really are too short for anything other than an entry weapon. 12.5 inches is currently en vogue, but I honestly think if you need a weapon that short in 5.56 you should just bite the bullet and go for a bullpup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Experiences in 'nam taught them it was a dumb fucking idea. Choppers are extremely vulnerable to even small arms fire no matter how much armor you put on it. In fact, armor is detrimental to virtually all flight characteristics of a helo.

Stand-off attack choppers with accurate PGMs and swivel mounted chainguns have proven to be far more effective and safe than trying to saturate with rockets and cannon fire. A chopper will have a hard time doing the former while carrying infantry, so you clear the LZ with the attack choppers working with fixed wing support and then the assault element - which doesn't have to be totally unarmed (Hueys and Blackhawks had their own panapoly of weapons) - can land safely under the constant overwatch of the attack choppers, whereas a Hind landing is very vulnerable.

Don't believe me? Ask the Soviets in Afghanistan and every war since - they quickly found that Hinds supporting a landing element of Hips was a lot better than trying to do both at once with the Hinds. That cargo space ended up only being used to carry a flight engineer or extra ammunition, or SAR - and it's telling on every chopper they've developed since that the cargo compartment vanished.

Those Gunship Blackhawks were originally intended to provide the navy with a cheap means of dealing with small surface combatants. This was because the Navy had no interested in purchasing navalized Apaches (like the British) or Super-Cobras from the muhreens. In fact, all the ammo and extra fire control equipment needed for the weapon pylons require the removal of all the passenger seats. So while they might share some similarities they actually fulfill two very different roles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56768824
Allow me to pitch in a bit.
I think it is just a matter of choice. Western designs probably preferred "modularity" , that is adding weaponry to cargo choppers as needed. And they did this because their production companies were more familiar with this method.
You might see some "subpar in both roles" arguments, but these are wrong.
When you built a chopper that is supposed to carry an autocannon, turret, it's ammo and 4 hard points on which you can mount as much as 16 large guided missiles, adding a passenger space to it is not as demanding as it is. The speed is mainly limited by "retreating blade stall", same for maneuverability. You can mount an engine powerfull enough to compensate for drag and extra load. Also when you don' have to carry passengers you mount a huge internal fuel tank inside, which greatly increases range.
The good side of Hind design is you get a decent design that can do a lot. Bad side is you are putting all your eggs in one basket.

The Kremlin has been trying to walk a tightrope of keeping the population calm and depoliticized while transitioning society and the economy onto a war footing, it can't be done quickly or people will panic (you saw it during the mobilization fiasco) but the central government has been slowly passing legislation to force private industry to begin making war materials and doubling and tripling shifts. This isn't a defensive war like WW2 and most Russians have really only accepted Putin remaining in power for so long because there has been an unofficial compact between the population and the state where they cede all political agency to the state and the state won't interfere with the population's ability to subsist. This war is already undermining that compact in fits and starts and further mobilization/nationalization of the economy will only strain it further. To make matters worse Russian industry can not domestically produce a lot of the more advanced components for their modern military equipment AND the demographic being targeted for mobilization is the same as the one that would work in these factories.

>>56779029
What do you think money is, retard? It's a proxy for barter, whether that's food and clothes or a multi-billion dollar factory. Russia does not have:
>The means to proxy this barter (ruble is basically a soviet-tier monopoly currency not usable or exchangeable outside of russia)
>The trust of anyone making deals with them
>Any access to the entities which have the resources, technology, personnel, etc that russia wants to barter for
Russia could have ten trillion dollars cash right now and it wouldn't do them any good, because they've been locked out of the marketplace. The only guys they have left are the mobsters and hobos (China, India, etc) willing to smuggle things out of the market - but of course, the best things are never within their reach.

Russia is completely unable to develop new and modern industry. All they can utilize is what they already had, and they have a disturbingly primitive industrial sector. They can't make a modern tank hull, let alone any of the electronics to go inside of it. They can't make aircraft parts, they can't make computer systems (or advanced software), they can't make anything except for crude materials which can easily be sourced elsewhere. It's unironically just over for Russia as any kind of economic or political power.

>>56780633
They indeed have very little debt, refer to

https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS?locations=RU

And it’s very bad. Even at this low debt ratio, 10 year bond yields are at 10%.
Meanwhile 10 year japanese bond yield is below 1%, even though Japan has way more than 200% of debt relative to GDP.

Nobody is willing to buy russian government debt unless with a big risk premium. Their currency is not freely convertible, meaning that they hand out bonds in other currency, usually USD or EUR. Because nobody wants their shitty currency. There is nothing you can buy with it. You also never have excess Ruble, because nothing they are selling internationally is traded in Ruble.
Russia has huge USD reserves from energy trades, but it can’t use them. Because, again, they are locked out from the majority of global trade. They are also in part forced to hold those to reduce bond yields.

Would you mind going through the fn49 cleaning process with corrosive ammo? Just want to make sure I don't overlook anything specific to the gun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56742170
Personally I have a spray bottle filled with 9 parts water, 1 part ballistol. I'll put the muzzle in a bucket, spray some down the barrel from the chamber, run a dry patch through it and wipe up the chamber area. Then I'll pop the gas piston out, spray the end of it and the plug with the stuff, dry them off. I'll get a rag or paper towel wet, run it through the gas tube. I also get the bolt out and wipe down the front end of it with the solution too. Then I'll repeat all these steps with either hoppes, pure ballistol, kroil, whatever's in arms reach. Hasn't failed yet.

Mauser 1893+ Action Power Rankings:

Really cool tier:
- Siamese T46, T46/66 and derivatives
- Spanish FR7/FR8
- Very rare 1893 pattern SA derivatives ("O.V.S" stamp M1895 Chilean, Paraguayan, Itajuba M954 and M968, El Salvadorean, etc.)
- Very rare FN export models (Luxembourg, Ethiopia, Congo Force Publique, Haiti, Morocco, FN 50, etc.)
- Madsen M47

Pretty cool tier:
- Non-German G98 derivatives (Radom, Brno vz22-vz24-vz33, FEG 43M, Yugo M47 and M48, etc.)
- Chinese
- Israeli postwar rebuild G98/K98k and FN
- P14 Enfield
- Less rare 1893 SA derivatives (Chilean, Mexican, Brazilian)
- Rare interwar and postwar short rifle derivatives (Persia, Syria, Costa Rica, etc.)

Not great, not terrible tier:
- Turkish
- US M1917
- FN 24 and derivatives
- Spanish 1893 pattern and derivatives (Swedish, Turkish, etc.)

Lame/overpriced shit tier:
- US M1903
- German G98, K98 and derivatives
- 1893 pattern carbines
- Argentine 1893 derivatives

>>56765329
>A
>two lugs on each side
Those look like Swedish M96 clips, not M98 clips. M98 clips have three lugs on each side. Swede clips are wider and don't fit in M98 guides (they're great in US rifles like the M1903 and M1917 however).

>>56765948
>Also, are these supposed to be numbers matching? The only serials on mine (without taking it all apart) are the receiver and the bolt, which don't match, which is unsurprising to me considering that they were rearsenaled.
Finns would have at least matched bolt to barrel serial. When rifles go through refurbishment at arsenal the parts considered important are re-numbered to match. To the Finns that was usually just the bolt, but sometimes other parts are also serialized. My Finn-captured m/91 has its stock serialized to the barrel, which is interesting because the stock is older than the barreled-action it's on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pointless rant time:

Can we all stop with MUH UNOBTAINABLE AMMO! or WOW SO EXPENSIVE TO SHOOT on cartridges PPU and other companies still make? And for stuff that is still very common for reloaders to make?

Half the time people post LE UNOBTAINABLE AMMO on here I can go find it in 20 seconds. For a while it was 7.5 Swiss which for 90% of the last year SGAmmo / Midway / AIM has had in stock no issue. Beyond this pretty much every (with some exceptions) smokeless centerfire cartridge you can get for old military rifles has one company loading it. For a few of them you just have to wait for the batches. 6.5 Carcano being an example, PPU still makes it. Multiple places had it this year but sold through, more will show up. If you don't load be patient and buy a couple cases when it arrives, same for 7.65 Argentine, new batches will show up from PPU.

Even rare BP cartridges and smokeless stuff like 6.5 Vergueiro has pages upon pages of boomers talking about loading them if you have a press. And hell Buffalo Arms will make you most of these if you pay $4 a round for them.

Finally is cost. I would say S&B and PPU are without a doubt the least affected ammo in terms of inflation and pricing going up. If you look at anyone that carries these online they are still $20-25 a box for the most part. Even price gouging SGAmmo lowered their prices on most of these to $21-25, AIM surplus is still low 20s on it also. This is pretty much on par with every single full size centerfire rifle cartridge minus .308/7.62 - which is the only round in this class I see under $1 a round regularly. .243 / .270 / 6.5 /.30-06 and the like are virtually all over $1 a round with many going well beyond that for hunting loads. Your ancient shit stick ammo for $22 a box from PPU is not expensive compared to modern loads.

Thanks for listening to my rant.

Unless you have previous experience don't expect to go anywhere past medical before they never accept your application. I was 19 when I applied, fit as can be and was going for priority secondary roles. My main was parachute rigger, 2nd was air force logistical and 3rd was army logistical. Me and 9 other people (5 blokes, one was gay, and 3 chicks) were sitting in the reception area. We all went through med at the same time then back to waiting. The chicks and the openly gay bloke went through psyche pretty soon after and all passed into job acceptance waiting log. EG, they got in. The rest of us though? All white straight blokes? They never even fucking saw us in psyche until one of the ADF guys who worked there told the psyche he had to see us. I went in, 3 minutes of talking, fucker told me I was not suitable to the forces because I was still living at home and not independent, because of course I was going to be straight out of high school. I was deferred for 5 years but just straight up ended my application there. The Australian military is in a state of recruitment quota filling, so unless your black, gay, a women or anything BUT a straight, white bloke, you most likely aren't getting in unless they are absolutely fucking hurting for a specific role, and those are always highly specialised ones, eg medical and engineering, and those always come with officer training.

TLDR: You're an older bloke trying to get into a job where every job has 500-100 people trying to get the same slot so THEY can get in during an increasingly quota filling for gender and race time in ADFR, you'll never get past psyche evul.
